:   "*When I finished constructing my lightsaber, Obi-Wan said to me, 'Anakin, this weapon is your life.' This weapon is my life.*"
:   ―Anakin Skywalker, to Padmé Amidala[[46]](#cite_note-Hostage_Crisis-46)

Anakin Skywalker wielded at least four lightsabers throughout his life. The first was a lightsaber constructed and used by Skywalker as a Padawan learner and Obi-Wan Kenobi's apprentice. When his lightsaber was destroyed on a droid factory assembly line on Geonosis, Skywalker briefly used a fallen Jedi's green-bladed weapon during the Battle of Geonosis and a lightsaber duel with Count Dooku, also the Sith Lord Darth Tyranus.[[14]](#cite_note-Episode_II-14) Skywalker soon constructed a second blue-bladed weapon that was similar to his first, which he used throughout the Clone Wars, in which he battled a variety of opponents, from Dooku to his Sith apprentice Asajj Ventress,[[19]](#cite_note-CloneWarsFilm-19) to bounty hunters such as Cad Bane.[[104]](#cite_note-Cargo_of_Doom-104) Even after Anakin Skywalker turned to the dark side and became the Sith Lord Darth Vader, he continued to use his Jedi weapon when he was ordered to attack the Jedi Temple on Coruscant and kill the Separatists on Mustafar. Following a duel with Kenobi on Mustafar, the former Jedi's master took the weapon after the now-Sith Lord's defeat;[[13]](#cite_note-Episode_III-13) Kenobi eventually gave the weapon to Anakin's son, Luke.[[21]](#cite_note-Episode_IV-21) Vader constructed a new weapon, one that was a black-alloy version of his original weapon with a red blade, that he used throughout the Imperial Era. The Sith Lord used his lightsaber against surviving Jedi, including his former Jedi apprentice Ahsoka Tano[[317]](#cite_note-Twilight_of_the_Apprentice-317) and several rematches with his old master Kenobi.[[292]](#cite_note-Part_IV-292)[[21]](#cite_note-Episode_IV-21) Although Vader's lightsaber won in battle against Luke's use of Anakin's lightsaber,[[15]](#cite_note-Episode_V-15) the Sith's lightsaber would be lost in his final duel with Luke and his death.[[5]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-5)

## Behind the scenes

### Development

:   "*What drove me to make these movies is that this is a really interesting story about how people go bad. In this particular case, the premise is: Nobody thinks they're bad. They simply have different points of view. This is about a kid that's really wonderful. He has some flaws—and those flaws ultimately do him in. The core issue, ultimately, is greed, possessiveness—the inability to let go. Not only to hold on to material things, which is greed, but to hold on to life, to the people you love—to not accept the reality of life's passages and changes, which is to say things come, things go. Everything changes. Anakin becomes emotionally attached to things, his mother, his wife. That's why he falls—because he does not have the ability to let go.*"
:   ―George Lucas[[540]](#cite_note-Making_of_Episode_III-540)

 [![Concept art of Darth Vader fighting the character that would become Luke Skywalker](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/54/MCQ-deakvader.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20070805220714) [![Concept art of Darth Vader fighting the character that would become Luke Skywalker](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/54/MCQ-deakvader.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/268?cb=20070805220714)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/54/MCQ-deakvader.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20070805220714) 

Concept art of Darth Vader fighting the character that would become Luke Skywalker

 

Anakin Skywalker, originally introduced as Darth Vader, made his first appearance as one of the primary antagonists in [*Star Wars*: Episode IV *A New Hope*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_IV_A_New_Hope "Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope").[[21]](#cite_note-Episode_IV-21) As the *Star Wars* universe continued to evolve, Skywalker's character would be developed and explored in detail, with [George Lucas](/wiki/George_Lucas "George Lucas") eventually making him into a central figure in the six initial *Star Wars* films. The character's popularity and focus would make him into a mascot of sorts for the *Star Wars* franchise, most commonly depicted in merchandise as the suited Vader.[[541]](#cite_note-Empire_of_Dreams-541) *[Star Wars: Behind the Magic](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Behind_the_Magic "Star Wars: Behind the Magic")* claimed Lucas intended the name "Darth Vader" to suggest "dark father."[[542]](#cite_note-BtM-542)

The character of Darth Vader was not originally planned to be a suited cyborg. In the original scripts for *A New Hope*, the name "Darth Vader" was given to a normal Imperial general. The concept of a cybernetic Vader was created when the concept artist drew the opening scene where *Tantive IV* was being boarded. It was initially imagined that Darth Vader would fly through space to enter the ship, necessitating a suit and breathing mask. This suit was later made permanent and incorporated in the story. Vader's usage of an all-black uniform, alongside his devotion to Emperor Palpatine, was also intended to be an analogy to the [*Schutzstaffel* (SS)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schutzstaffel "wikipedia:Schutzstaffel") in Nazi Germany.[[543]](#cite_note-SW:TMOM_146-543)

 [![Concept art of Anakin Skywalker as a child](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/c/ce/Anakin_Skywalker_Episode_1_Concept_Art.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20090612043757) [![Concept art of Anakin Skywalker as a child](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/c/ce/Anakin_Skywalker_Episode_1_Concept_Art.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/200?cb=20090612043757)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/c/ce/Anakin_Skywalker_Episode_1_Concept_Art.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20090612043757) 

Concept art of Anakin Skywalker as a child

 

In order to keep the "big secret" of [*Star Wars*: Episode V *The Empire Strikes Back*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_V_The_Empire_Strikes_Back "Star Wars: Episode V The Empire Strikes Back") under wraps from potential film spies, Lucas actually used a diversion technique: actor [David Prowse](/wiki/David_Prowse "David Prowse") was instructed to say, "Obi-Wan killed your father" during filming. Later, [James Earl Jones](/wiki/James_Earl_Jones "James Earl Jones")' voice was dubbed in, revealing the actual truth of Vader's progeny in the famous line, "*I* am your father." The only ones who knew this big secret were the writers, [Mark Hamill](/wiki/Mark_Hamill "Mark Hamill") (who was told in secret moments before shooting the scene), and Jones.[[541]](#cite_note-Empire_of_Dreams-541) There have been claims that George Lucas took the name "Anakin" from his friend and fellow film director Ken Annakin. However, Lucas denied this via his publicist following Annakin's death in 2009.[[544]](#cite_note-kenannakin-544)

In Lucas's draft script for [*Star Wars*: Episode VI *Return of the Jedi*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_VI_Return_of_the_Jedi "Star Wars: Episode VI Return of the Jedi"), Vader would have encountered Yoda and Kenobi once more when the Force spirits of both Jedi Masters appeared aboard the second Death Star, deflecting Darth Sidious's Force lightning when he attacked Luke Skywalker. Another change came at the end of the film: the redeemed Anakin Skywalker, along with Yoda and Kenobi, would have returned to life and received a hug from his son. Writing about this draft script for the *[Star Wars Insider](/wiki/Star_Wars_Insider "Star Wars Insider")* article "[Rewind of the Jedi](/wiki/Rewind_of_the_Jedi "Rewind of the Jedi")," [James Floyd](/wiki/James_Floyd "James Floyd") joked that Skywalker's survival could have swayed Ben Solo away from the dark side due to his experience on such matters.[[545]](#cite_note-Rewind_of_the_Jedi-545)

Darth Vader's burned helmet appears in the [2015](/wiki/2015 "2015") film [*Star Wars*: Episode VII *The Force Awakens*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_VII_The_Force_Awakens "Star Wars: Episode VII The Force Awakens"), the first entry within the [sequel trilogy](/wiki/Sequel_trilogy "Sequel trilogy"). Having Anakin appear in the film as a Force spirit or in a Force vision was a topic of debate among the filmmakers: concept artist [Iain McCaig](/wiki/Iain_McCaig "Iain McCaig"), while inspired by the phrase "When you light a candle, you also cast a shadow," created a [2013](/wiki/2013 "2013") artwork depicting Anakin's ghost morphing back and forth between both of his identities.[[546]](#cite_note-TFA_Art-546) However, according to [Phil Szostak](/wiki/Phil_Szostak "Phil Szostak"), McCaig pitched the idea but was unprompted by [J.J. Abrams](/wiki/J.J._Abrams "J.J. Abrams") or any member of the film's crew.[[547]](#cite_note-547) As far as Szostak recalls, Anakin's Force ghost artwork was not from an early film draft or treatment.[[548]](#cite_note-548) Skywalker actor [Hayden Christensen](/wiki/Hayden_Christensen "Hayden Christensen") was originally approached to reprise the role, but Anakin's inclusion in the film was ultimately dropped,[[549]](#cite_note-549) although Christensen has since returned to the role on several occasions,[[303]](#cite_note-Part_VI-303)[[501]](#cite_note-Part_Five-501) including a vocal cameo in the sequel trilogy's [2019](/wiki/2019 "2019") finale [*Star Wars*: Episode IX *The Rise of Skywalker*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_IX_The_Rise_of_Skywalker "Star Wars: Episode IX The Rise of Skywalker").[[514]](#cite_note-Episode_VIII-514)

On both the [2005](/wiki/2005 "2005") DVD cover of [*Star Wars*: Episode III *Revenge of the Sith*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_III_Revenge_of_the_Sith "Star Wars: Episode III Revenge of the Sith") and the film's poster, the scar on the right side of Skywalker's face is absent.

Anakin, along with certain actions of his, have been represented by numerous musical motifs during the film scores. These include "[Anakin's Theme](/wiki/Anakin%27s_Theme "Anakin's Theme")," "[Anakin's Betrayal](/wiki/Anakin%27s_Betrayal "Anakin's Betrayal")," "[Anakin's Dark Deeds](/wiki/Anakin%27s_Dark_Deeds "Anakin's Dark Deeds")," "[Across the Stars](/wiki/Across_the_Stars "Across the Stars")" (his love theme with Padmé), and "[The Imperial March](/wiki/The_Imperial_March "The Imperial March")" (as Darth Vader).

### Darth Vader as a cultural figure

 [![Vader's image has joined other mythic and historical figures as a symbol for evil.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/b/b0/DarthVader-CotF.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20111223224557) [![Vader's image has joined other mythic and historical figures as a symbol for evil.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/b/b0/DarthVader-CotF.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/213?cb=20111223224557)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/b/b0/DarthVader-CotF.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20111223224557) 

Vader's image has joined other mythic and historical figures as a symbol for evil.

 

Due to his central role in the films, Vader has entered the public consciousness as one of the most iconic characters in cinema history[[550]](#cite_note-SpecialEdition-550) and a quintessential frightening villain; the [American Film Institute's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Film_Institute "wikipedia:American Film Institute") list of the greatest movie villains placed him third, after Hannibal Lecter and Norman Bates.[[551]](#cite_note-heroesvillains-551) Further, the character has come to represent power, tragedy, and redemption.[[550]](#cite_note-SpecialEdition-550) Lord Vader's powerful, basso profondo voice coupled with his heavy, eerie breathing is easily recognizable to moviegoers— it is symbolic of his transformation from a man of the light to an evil cyborg.

Vader has been heavily parodied and imitated by other characters in popular culture.[[552]](#cite_note-TV_Tropes-552) He has been mocked by such figures as "[Heinz Darthenshmirtz](/wiki/Heinz_Darthenshmirtz "Heinz Darthenshmirtz")" in *[Phineas and Ferb: Star Wars](/wiki/Phineas_and_Ferb:_Star_Wars "Phineas and Ferb: Star Wars")*,[[553]](#cite_note-PandFSW-553) "Dark Helmet" from [*Spaceballs*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spaceballs "wikipedia:Spaceballs"), and countless other parodies from cartoons, such as "Duck Vader" from Tiny Toon Adventures and "Darth Koopa" from the *Super Mario Bros.* TV series. Other fictional characters follow Vader's archetype in a more serious manner. One example would be "Death's Hand" from the video game Jade Empire—who was similarly imprisoned in a suit of armor, including a masked helmet, although using magic rather than cybernetics. Other similar character would be [Dr Doppler](https://megaman.fandom.com/wiki/Dr._Doppler), the main antagonist from the videogame [Rockman X3](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mega_Man_X3) who after similarly being corrupted by a different character, modified his own body and later sacrificed himself to destroy the villain, save the protagonist and redeem himself. Another example is the primary antagonist of [*Final Fantasy IV*](https://finalfantasy.fandom.com/wiki/Final_Fantasy_IV "w:c:finalfantasy:Final Fantasy IV"), [Golbez](https://finalfantasy.fandom.com/wiki/Golbez "w:c:finalfantasy:Golbez"), who [Takashi Tokita](https://finalfantasy.fandom.com/wiki/Takashi_Tokita "w:c:finalfantasy:Takashi Tokita") stated was based on Darth Vader. Similar to Vader, Golbez had been turned to evil by an outside influence due to traumatic experiences, primarily wore dark armor after his fall, and was a relative of the main protagonist (his brother, in this case).[[554]](#cite_note-554) The incarnation of [Bane](https://batman.fandom.com/wiki/Bane_(Tom_Hardy) "w:c:batman:Bane (Tom Hardy)") in the [Batman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batman "wikipedia:Batman") film [*The Dark Knight Rises*](https://batman.fandom.com/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_Rises "w:c:batman:The Dark Knight Rises") also takes inspiration from Vader, particularly due to his hulking size and high intellect (retained from other incarnations of the character), along with his unique mask and distinctive breathing.[[555]](#cite_note-555) Within *Star Wars* canon, the character of Kylo Ren is not only inspired by Vader, but aspires to be like him [in-universe](/wiki/In-universe "In-universe") and has a similar appearance and personality to Anakin prior to his injuries.[[508]](#cite_note-Episode_VII-508)

Vader was also referenced in the 1982 *Space: 1999* compilation film *Cosmic Princess*, as Captain Duro from the Year Two episode "Space Warp" was renamed "Vader, commander of the Whills Interplanetary Starfleet" in reference to the [*Journal of the Whills*](/wiki/Journal_of_the_Whills,_Part_I "Journal of the Whills, Part I"), by George Lucas.[[556]](#cite_note-556)

Furthermore, Darth Vader's name has become a synonym for frightening evil. During the later phase of its construction, [Washington National Cathedral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_National_Cathedral "wikipedia:Washington National Cathedral") held a competition for children to design new [grotesques](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grotesque "wikipedia:Grotesque") for the west towers. One winner was [a design featuring Darth Vader](http://www.nationalcathedral.org/about/darthVader.shtml) ([backup link](https://web.archive.org/web/20181119085153/https://cathedral.org/what-to-see/exterior/vader)).

Lucas once mentioned in an interview that he based Darth Vader on the android villain Hakaider from the 1972–73 live-action Japanese television series *Jinzo Ningen Kikaider*, which he watched while visiting Japan in the early 1970s. The book *[Star Wars: The Complete Vader](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Complete_Vader "Star Wars: The Complete Vader")* explored the cultural impact of the Vader character in detail.[[557]](#cite_note-The_Complete_Vader-557)

 [![A boy dressed as Vader in an advertisement for Volkswagen](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/4/44/Star_Wars_Volkswagen_Commercial.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20110207180859) [![A boy dressed as Vader in an advertisement for Volkswagen](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/4/44/Star_Wars_Volkswagen_Commercial.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/229?cb=20110207180859)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/4/44/Star_Wars_Volkswagen_Commercial.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20110207180859) 

A boy dressed as Vader in an advertisement for Volkswagen

 

In [2011](/wiki/2011 "2011") and [2012](/wiki/2012 "2012"), the luxury car company Volkswagen aired two Super Bowl commercials featuring the character of Darth Vader. The first ad was entitled "[The Force](/wiki/The_Force_(Volkswagen) "The Force (Volkswagen)")" and featured a young boy wearing a costume of Darth Vader's armor. The boy attempted to use the Force to pull his parents' car to him but ran away when the car's alarm sounded, his parents watching from the window. The 2012 commercial aired after a different ad for Volkswagen that did not feature Vader. It featured Darth Vader strangling Doctor [Cornelius Evazan](/wiki/Cornelius_Evazan "Cornelius Evazan") because Evazan had commented that the new commercial was more moving than the Vader one from the previous year.[[558]](#cite_note-Super_Bowl_2012-558)

### Portrayal

:   "*Finding the right voice for Darth Vader was another challenge. Lucas never intended to use the on-set vocal performance of David Prowse.*"
:   ―Narrator Robert Clotworthy[[541]](#cite_note-Empire_of_Dreams-541)

Darth Vader, as he was initially established, was portrayed on-set by [David Prowse](/wiki/David_Prowse "David Prowse") in the [original trilogy](/wiki/Original_trilogy "Original trilogy"), while [James Earl Jones](/wiki/James_Earl_Jones "James Earl Jones") provided the iconic voice of the suited Vader,[[15]](#cite_note-Episode_V-15) a role that he reprised for *Star Wars*: Episode III *Revenge of the Sith*,[[13]](#cite_note-Episode_III-13) *[Star Tours: The Adventures Continue](/wiki/Star_Tours:_The_Adventures_Continue "Star Tours: The Adventures Continue")*,[[559]](#cite_note-SW_obituary-559) *[Star Wars Rebels](/wiki/Star_Wars_Rebels "Star Wars Rebels")*,[[29]](#cite_note-Spark_of_Rebellion-29) *[Rogue One: A Star Wars Story](/wiki/Rogue_One:_A_Star_Wars_Story "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story")*,[[560]](#cite_note-EWJune-560) *Star Wars*: Episode IX *The Rise of Skywalker*,[[527]](#cite_note-Episode_IX-527) and the *[Star Wars: Obi-Wan Kenobi](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Obi-Wan_Kenobi "Star Wars: Obi-Wan Kenobi")* television series.[[300]](#cite_note-Part_III-300)[[559]](#cite_note-SW_obituary-559) [Sebastian Shaw](/wiki/Sebastian_Shaw "Sebastian Shaw") played the dying Anakin, his head freed from his cybernetic armor in *Star Wars*: Episode VI *Return of the Jedi*.[[5]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-5)

[*Star Wars*: Episode I *The Phantom Menace*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_I_The_Phantom_Menace "Star Wars: Episode I The Phantom Menace") featured Anakin Skywalker as a nine-year-old boy, a role that was landed by then child actor [Jake Lloyd](/wiki/Jake_Lloyd "Jake Lloyd")[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_I-12) after casting director [Robin Gurland](/wiki/Robin_Gurland "Robin Gurland") looked at three thousand different actors to play the role.[[561]](#cite_note-TP-561) Hayden Christensen played Skywalker in both [*Star Wars*: Episode II *Attack of the Clones*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_II_Attack_of_the_Clones "Star Wars: Episode II Attack of the Clones") and *Star Wars*: Episode III *Revenge of the Sith*.[[14]](#cite_note-Episode_II-14)[[13]](#cite_note-Episode_III-13) Christensen auditioned for the role of adult Skywalker with no concept that he would get the part.[[562]](#cite_note-Return-562) Christensen and [Ewan McGregor](/wiki/Ewan_McGregor "Ewan McGregor"), the actor who played Kenobi in the [prequel trilogy](/wiki/Prequel_trilogy "Prequel trilogy"), practiced lightsaber rehearsals, which Christensen said was the most fun he had, and he described it as "playing with your friend every day."[[563]](#cite_note-17_year-563)

Christensen's voice was later heard in a cameo in Episode IX *The Rise of Skywalker*.[[527]](#cite_note-Episode_IX-527) Hayden Christensen reprised the role of Anakin Skywalker / Darth Vader in the *Obi-Wan Kenobi* television series, alongside Jones.[[300]](#cite_note-Part_III-300)

In the [*Star Wars: The Clone Wars* film](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_(film) "Star Wars: The Clone Wars (film)"), [television series](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars "Star Wars: The Clone Wars"), *[Star Wars Rebels](/wiki/Star_Wars_Rebels "Star Wars Rebels")*, *[Star Wars Forces of Destiny](/wiki/Star_Wars_Forces_of_Destiny "Star Wars Forces of Destiny")*, and *[Star Wars: Tales of the Jedi](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Tales_of_the_Jedi_(television_series) "Star Wars: Tales of the Jedi (television series)")* the character of Anakin Skywalker was voiced by [Matt Lanter](/wiki/Matt_Lanter "Matt Lanter").[[19]](#cite_note-CloneWarsFilm-19) In *Rogue One*, Vader is portrayed by both [Spencer Wilding](/wiki/Spencer_Wilding "Spencer Wilding") and [Daniel Naprous](/wiki/Daniel_Naprous "Daniel Naprous").[[564]](#cite_note-564)[[565]](#cite_note-565) [Lucasfilm](/wiki/Lucasfilm "Lucasfilm") president [Kathleen Kennedy](/wiki/Kathleen_Kennedy "Kathleen Kennedy") said that Christensen was not considered to play Vader in *Rogue One* because the scene of Vader chasing the rebels "was just such a specific action sequence." Christensen was not part of any of the conversations about *Rogue One*, but he loved what the film did with the character and he thought it was brilliant.[[563]](#cite_note-17_year-563)

Prowse was originally intended to talk in Vader's armor, although his West Country accent made Vader seem too silly, so his voice was quickly replaced. Jones decided to do the voice work, as the need for Vader to sound intimidating matched his own voice.[[541]](#cite_note-Empire_of_Dreams-541) Prowse, however, was not aware that his voice was replaced until the film's release. Jones was not credited until Episode VI, as he felt he did not deserve the credit due to only supplying his voice for Vader. For fight scenes in Episodes V and VI, swordsman [Bob Anderson](/wiki/Bob_Anderson "Bob Anderson") wore the suit. In new footage shot for the [Special Edition](/wiki/The_Star_Wars_Trilogy_Special_Edition "The Star Wars Trilogy Special Edition") of the original trilogy, actor and former [Industrial Light & Magic](/wiki/Industrial_Light_%26_Magic "Industrial Light & Magic") visual effects artist [C. Andrew Nelson](/wiki/C._Andrew_Nelson "C. Andrew Nelson") played the infamous Dark Lord.

[![](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/e/ee/Spirits_copy1.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20230516034943)

[![](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/55/JediGhosts-ROTJ.png/revision/latest?cb=20201008104501)

The spirit of Anakin Skywalker was originally portrayed by Sebastian Shaw before being replaced by Hayden Christensen.

In the original *Return of the Jedi*, Skywalker's redeemed Force ghost was a robust, middle-aged to elderly man with graying brown hair and a kindly face, but upon release of the Special Edition DVD of *Return of the Jedi*, Skywalker is in his twenties just before his fall to the dark side. George Lucas stated that redeemed Jedi would revert as a Force ghost to their pre-fall form.

In *Revenge of the Sith*, Christensen briefly wore the Vader suit, which the costume department specifically designed to fit his body.[[566]](#cite_note-Vader's_armor_old_DB-566) The actor had a difficult time moving around in the suit, and it was extremely rigid. When he told Lucas about this, the director suggested that wearing the suit should feel very mechanical and unnatural.[[567]](#cite_note-Specialist-567) His stand-in double for the UK shoot was [Christian J Simpson](/wiki/Christian_Simpson "Christian Simpson"), who also played alongside the young Skywalker in Episode I as [Bravo Six](/wiki/Bravo_Six/Legends "Bravo Six/Legends"), Lt. [Gavyn Sykes](/wiki/Gavyn_Sykes/Legends "Gavyn Sykes/Legends"). The few lines of the suited Vader speaking are of Jones, but at one time, there was some debate over this. Some fans believed that he did not participate at all, since his name does not appear in the credits of *Revenge of the Sith*, and the voice heard in the first trailer for the movie was Christensen's, albeit altered digitally. The matter was settled with the Summer 2005 issue of [*Starlog*](/wiki/Starlog_(magazine) "Starlog (magazine)"), in which producer [Rick McCallum](/wiki/Rick_McCallum "Rick McCallum") stated they had Jones for a partial day of work on *Revenge of the Sith*.

In the [Legends](/wiki/Star_Wars_Legends "Star Wars Legends") [radio-drama adaptations](/wiki/Star_Wars_(radio) "Star Wars (radio)"), [Brock Peters](/wiki/Brock_Peters "Brock Peters") performed as Vader, with [David Birney](/wiki/David_Birney "David Birney") performing as Skywalker on the final episode of the *Return of the Jedi* radio drama. Legacy audio of Peters was used for the [canonical](/wiki/Canon "Canon") [2015](/wiki/2015 "2015") release [*Episode IV: A New Hope Read-Along Storybook and CD*](/wiki/A_New_Hope_Read-Along_Storybook_and_CD "A New Hope Read-Along Storybook and CD"). In the [*Clone Wars* cartoon](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Clone_Wars "Star Wars: Clone Wars"), Skywalker was voiced by [Frankie Ryan Manriquez](/wiki/Frankie_Ryan_Manriquez "Frankie Ryan Manriquez") as a child and [Mat Lucas](/wiki/Mat_Lucas "Mat Lucas") as an adult. In *The Clone Wars* CGI series and its feature film, the character is voiced by Matt Lanter. For many of the *Star Wars* video games, including *[Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Galactic_Battlegrounds "Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds")*, *[Star Wars: Force Commander](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Force_Commander "Star Wars: Force Commander")*, and [*Star Wars: TIE Fighter*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_TIE_Fighter_(video_game) "Star Wars: TIE Fighter (video game)"), Vader was voiced by [Scott Lawrence](/wiki/Scott_Lawrence "Scott Lawrence"); in titles, such as *[Star Wars: The Force Unleashed](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Force_Unleashed "Star Wars: The Force Unleashed")* and *[Star Wars: Empire at War](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Empire_at_War "Star Wars: Empire at War")*, [Matthew Sloan](/wiki/Matthew_Sloan "Matthew Sloan"), who provides the voice of Vader in the [*Chad Vader: Day Shift Manager*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chad_Vader:_Day_Shift_Manager "wikipedia:Chad Vader: Day Shift Manager") shorts, provides Vader's voice.

In the Japanese localizations, [Daisuke Namikawa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daisuke_Namikawa "wikipedia:Daisuke Namikawa") acts as the voice of Anakin as an adult, while as young Anakin, [Akiko Yajima](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akiko_Yajima "wikipedia:Akiko Yajima") provides his voice in the Clone Wars. As Darth Vader, the voice is provided by [Tōru Ōhira](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T%C5%8Dru_%C5%8Chira "wikipedia:Tōru Ōhira") in most incarnations starting with the DVD release, save for *Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds* (where he is voiced by [Ryūzaburō Ōtomo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ry%C5%ABzabur%C5%8D_%C5%8Ctomo "wikipedia:Ryūzaburō Ōtomo")), and a number of other substitute voices in the original films. Ōhira also by proxy, reprises his role in the Japanese version of *[SoulCalibur IV](/wiki/Soulcalibur_IV "Soulcalibur IV")*. After Ōhira's death, the role was taken up by [Taiten Kusunoki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taiten_Kusunoki "wikipedia:Taiten Kusunoki") for *Rebels* onwards.

In the original ending of *Rogue One*, the final scene for Darth Vader was not him attacking and chasing the Rebels with the Death Star plans. Instead, Vader was going to kill Krennic.[[568]](#cite_note-Krennic_fate-568) In the comic series *[Star Wars: Bounty Hunters](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Bounty_Hunters "Star Wars: Bounty Hunters")*, Vader is drawn in a very kinetic fashion by artist [Paolo Villanelli](/wiki/Paolo_Villanelli "Paolo Villanelli"), whose favorite *Star Wars* character is none-other-than Vader. In fact, it was Villanelli's love for Vader that convinced writer [Ethan Sacks](/wiki/Ethan_Sacks "Ethan Sacks") to push for his inclusion. To ensure he could use the Sith Lord, he spoke with line editor [Mark Paniccia](/wiki/Mark_Paniccia "Mark Paniccia") and [Greg Pak](/wiki/Greg_Pak "Greg Pak"), writer of the concurrent *[Star Wars: Darth Vader](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Darth_Vader_(2020) "Star Wars: Darth Vader (2020)")* comic series. To Sacks, the kinetic way Villanelli draw Vader was proof of his love for the character. In an interview with *[Star Wars Insider](/wiki/Star_Wars_Insider "Star Wars Insider")* where he said as such, he also lauded Pak for the way he was able to get into Vader's character in *Darth Vader*.[[569]](#cite_note-224_Sacks_Interview-569)

### *Obi-Wan Kenobi* and *Ahsoka*

:   "*Vader is played by three people, we all worked together to create the best Darth Vader in cinematic history. It's me, it's Hayden [Christensen], It's Tom [O'Connell]. We are a symbiosis. We all contributed our strengths to create the best representation of the character.[…] Hayden and I both act in the Darth Vader scenes, we bring the character and the emotions (and the pain, suffering, anger) I'm 6'7 so when you see a full body shot it looks better having an actor, vs a CGI creation. Tom specializes in the fighting. The fights are Tom. Full body with Helmet On is me, Hayden carries the heaviest burden of all, the pain and betrayal of his best friend and once mentor.*"
:   ―Dmitrious Bistrevsky[[570]](#cite_note-Dmitrious_Instagram-570)

In a meeting, writer [Stuart Beattie](/wiki/Stuart_Beattie "Stuart Beattie") explained that his two core ideas for an Obi-Wan Kenobi project involved Kenobi leaving Tatooine and coming face-to-face with Darth Vader. He was told that neither of those could happen, so he cited *Return of the Jedi* when Vader told Luke Skywalker that Kenobi once believed there was still good in him. Beattie explained that this never happened in *Revenge of the Sith*, which convinced them that he had a point. He added that people would need to believe that Vader killed Anakin Skywalker. This convinced the team to hire Beattie to write the script for the first of three Kenobi feature films. One of his main purposes in writing the story was to show Kenobi going on a journey to accept the fact that Anakin Skywalker had been killed by Vader.[[571]](#cite_note-Vader_originally_won_battle-571)

 [![Concept art of a lightsaber duel between Obi-Wan Kenobi and Darth Vader](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/f/f5/Obi-WanKenobiVsDarthVaderConceptArt.png/revision/latest?cb=20220828182913) [![Concept art of a lightsaber duel between Obi-Wan Kenobi and Darth Vader](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/f/f5/Obi-WanKenobiVsDarthVaderConceptArt.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/230?cb=20220828182913)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/f/f5/Obi-WanKenobiVsDarthVaderConceptArt.png/revision/latest?cb=20220828182913) 

Concept art of a lightsaber duel between Obi-Wan Kenobi and Darth Vader

 

Beattie wrote Vader as being obsessed with Kenobi and revenge. From the beginning of Beattie's story, Emperor Palpatine would tell Vader to forget Kenobi and focus on the present problems. The film would begin with Vader taking on five Jedi and killing them, which Beattie wanted to establish that Vader was "the big Jedi killer." In one scene, Palpatine sent Vader to crush a rebel uprising and he was trying to forget Kenobi. Vader told Palpatine that Kenobi and Yoda were the two biggest threats, causing Palpatine to get angry and remind Vader of his place.[[571]](#cite_note-Vader_originally_won_battle-571) Kenobi told the Inquisitor Reva that Vader was Anakin Skywalker, allowing her realize she had been wrong the whole time. Reva then told Vader that she killed Kenobi, prompting him to kill the Inquisitor. This action saved Kenobi and ended Vader's obsession with the Jedi Master.[[572]](#cite_note-Reva_killed_in_script-572) Vader and Kenobi would duel on a space station that was falling apart in the atmosphere of a large planet. The whole story would build up to Kenobi taking off or slashing Vader's helmet and giving him a scar. Vader would push Kenobi off and he would not have the chance to find Kenobi. Seeing Skywalker's face would have convinced Kenobi that Vader killed Skywalker. Beattie found it important to separate the two during the duel because he believed Kenobi would kill Vader if he had the chance. At the end of the story, Vader would believe Kenobi was dead, which would explain why Vader stopped hunting Kenobi and justify why he was shocked to learn that his master was alive in *A New Hope*. Beattie's story was eventually turned into the first season of the *Obi-Wan Kenobi* television series.[[571]](#cite_note-Vader_originally_won_battle-571)

During production of the series, the creative team began remapping Kenobi's story and they went through an internal debate about whether Vader should return.[[563]](#cite_note-17_year-563) Director [Deborah Chow](/wiki/Deborah_Chow "Deborah Chow") wanted Vader to return because he was important to Kenobi in his life.[[573]](#cite_note-Return_of_Vader-573) She believed that there is a "love-story dynamic" between Kenobi and Vader, so she felt like it was difficult to not include the person who left Kenobi in a state of anguish. Chow was intrigued by the idea that Kenobi might still care deeply about Vader despite what he had become.[[574]](#cite_note-Rebellion_televised-574) The debate carried on for a long time and was talked about constantly.[[563]](#cite_note-17_year-563) The crew questioned whether introducing Vader in the story would detract from their duel on the Death Star in *A New Hope*.[[574]](#cite_note-Rebellion_televised-574) The team was aware that they were under a high level of scrutiny from the fans, and they figured a story point such as Vader returning would be highly scrutinized. Eventually, it was decided that Vader would appear in the series and he would be played by Christensen again. Writer [Joby Harold](/wiki/Joby_Harold "Joby Harold") thought it was important to have Christensen be a part of the project because he was a massive part of the character. Harold said that the whole crew made it a priority to handle Vader with as much care as possible "to honor one of the greatest villains and antagonists in the history of entertainment."[[563]](#cite_note-17_year-563)

When Harold was writing Vader, he wanted to trump Vader's scene in the ending of *Rogue One: A Star Wars Story*. At one point, Vader was a lot more extreme, though Harold got pulled back a little bit. For the scenes on Mapuzo, Harold decided that Vader had to express his feelings in action to reveal the character beneath.[[575]](#cite_note-Vader_terrifying-575) During the writing process, Harold thought of having Kenobi learn that Anakin Skywalker survived their duel on Mustafar to get the series to a place of intense drama for Kenobi. He first had to ask[[576]](#cite_note-Harold_justified-576) *Star Wars* lore advisor[[532]](#cite_note-Part_I-532) [Pablo Hidalgo](/wiki/Pablo_Hidalgo "Pablo Hidalgo") how much Kenobi knows during the show's time period, and Harold was given permission to use the scene.[[576]](#cite_note-Harold_justified-576) Harold had Kenobi and Vader duel in the series because he found that there was no line in a *A New Hope* that said they could not. Harold said the key to the duel on Mapuzo and Vader is feeling and articulating the range and anger under it all. He also wanted to find ways to feel the rivalry between the characters and to define the opportunities that are present in the fight.[[577]](#cite_note-Leia_Secret-577)

 [![Hayden Christensen training for a lightsaber duel with Ross Kohnstam](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/3/32/HaydenChristensenTrainsWithRossKohnstam.png/revision/latest?cb=20220829223340) [![Hayden Christensen training for a lightsaber duel with Ross Kohnstam](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/3/32/HaydenChristensenTrainsWithRossKohnstam.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/200?cb=20220829223340)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/3/32/HaydenChristensenTrainsWithRossKohnstam.png/revision/latest?cb=20220829223340) 

Hayden Christensen training for a lightsaber duel with Ross Kohnstam

 

In the fall of [2019](/wiki/2019 "2019"),[[574]](#cite_note-Rebellion_televised-574) director [Deborah Chow](/wiki/Deborah_Chow "Deborah Chow") went to Christensen's farm to make her pitch in person. Chow talked about the project and her vision for it.[[563]](#cite_note-17_year-563) She promised that Vader would add a new dimension that could reframe the way fans look at their duel in *A New Hope*.[[574]](#cite_note-Rebellion_televised-574) Christensen thought it sounded wonderful and was excited to return to *Star Wars*. When Christensen first came on the set, Chow thought it was intense to have an iconic character and that she was able to direct and film new scenes with him.[[563]](#cite_note-17_year-563) When Chow became the showrunner, she championed a rematch between Kenobi and Vader as Lucasfilm contemplated going that route. In [March](/wiki/March "March"), [2020](/wiki/2020 "2020"), Vader's return was finalized.[[574]](#cite_note-Rebellion_televised-574)

To prepare for playing Vader again, Christensen watched all of the *Star Wars* films, *Star Wars: The Clone Wars*, and *Star Wars Rebels*,[[578]](#cite_note-Kenobi_preparation-578) and he read some of the comics.[[579]](#cite_note-Kino_Plus-579) He also practiced with a lightsaber with McGregor's stunt double, [Ross Kohnstam](/wiki/Ross_Kohnstam "Ross Kohnstam").[[574]](#cite_note-Rebellion_televised-574) Harold said that Vader's shadow was cast over much of production of the show and Vader was written to be there emotionally for Kenobi and possibly beyond.[[580]](#cite_note-Vader_photos-580) Vader was meant to not be as fully formed as he was in *A New Hope*.[[573]](#cite_note-Return_of_Vader-573) Chow and the crew made sure that Darth Vader was not overused in order to keep the character's mystique.[[581]](#cite_note-Rotten_Tomatoes_TV-581)

 [![Darth Vader was played by stunt doubles Tom O'Connell (left) and Dmitrious Bistrevsky (right), and their movement coordinator was Olga Sokolova](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/07/VaderStuntDoublesandMovementCoach.png/revision/latest?cb=20220904221552) [![Darth Vader was played by stunt doubles Tom O'Connell (left) and Dmitrious Bistrevsky (right), and their movement coordinator was Olga Sokolova](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/07/VaderStuntDoublesandMovementCoach.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/200?cb=20220904221552)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/07/VaderStuntDoublesandMovementCoach.png/revision/latest?cb=20220904221552) 

Darth Vader was played by stunt doubles Tom O'Connell (left) and Dmitrious Bistrevsky (right), and their movement coordinator was Olga Sokolova

 

Vader was played by Christensen, [Dmitrious Bistrevsky](/wiki/Dmitrious_Bistrevsky "Dmitrious Bistrevsky"), and [Tom O'Connell](/wiki/Tom_O%27Connell "Tom O'Connell").[[570]](#cite_note-Dmitrious_Instagram-570) Christensen wore a Vader costume that was very hot and heavy, but there was an under-layer with cooling liquid in it. Between takes, Christensen was plugged into a device that circulated the liquid and helped him cool down. Christensen said that the mechanical element made him feel more like Vader.[[582]](#cite_note-Timeout-582) The costume also had tinted helmet lenses.[[563]](#cite_note-17_year-563) [Olga Sokolova](/wiki/Olga_Sokolova "Olga Sokolova"), a choreographer and "Vader movement specialist," made sure that Christensen moved and walked correctly in the suit. This was done because the actor wanted to stay true to how Vader moves and how he is perceived by fans.[[567]](#cite_note-Specialist-567) It took Christensen nine months to gain 25-30 pounds to fit in the suit.[[583]](#cite_note-Fatherly-583) Bistrevsky wore the suit during full body shots with the helmet on while O'Connell wore the suit during fighting scenes. Bistrevsky spent five months of training for the role and he learned all of his lines. He said that it was dark and heavy in the suit. While on set, he used meditation to stay in Vader's mindset. Some scenes required switching back and forth between multiple actors. Sokolova worked as Bistrevsky's movement coach and consultant, and she gave him notes in real time via a secret hand language. The first scene shot of Bistrevsky was the street scene on Mapuzo. Bistrevsky quickly learned that speaking with anger made the helmet shake, so his friend Dorian voice acted the scene, and Bistrevsky would act to his intensity while adding his own character voices.[[570]](#cite_note-Dmitrious_Instagram-570)

When Christensen spoke Vader's lines on set, he pulled aspects from James Earl Jones' delivery and intonation.[[584]](#cite_note-Christensen_Jones_voice-584) [Skywalker Sound](/wiki/Skywalker_Sound "Skywalker Sound") hired the [Ukrainian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukraine "wikipedia:Ukraine") start-up company [Respeecher](/wiki/Respeecher "Respeecher") to artificially create Vader's voice for the series, which uses archival recordings and a proprietary A.I. algorithm to create new dialogue with the voices of performers. Respeecher, which also created the voice of young Luke Skywalker for *[Star Wars: The Book of Boba Fett](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Book_of_Boba_Fett "Star Wars: The Book of Boba Fett")*, was used because Jones's voice has altered with age and he has stepped back from the role. After *The Rise of Skywalker*, Jones had mentioned he was looking into winding down Vader. [Matthew Wood](/wiki/Matthew_Wood "Matthew Wood") presented Jones with Respeecher's work, and the actor signed off on using his archival voice recordings to keep Vader alive and vital even by artificial means.[[585]](#cite_note-Respeecher-585)

Jones is credited for guiding the performance on *Obi-Wan Kenobi*. Wood described his contribution as "a benevolent godfather." They informed the actor about their plans for Vader and heeded his advice on how to stay on the right course. Respeecher finished work on the series amid the 2022 [Russian invasion of Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "wikipedia:Russian invasion of Ukraine"). While he stated the alternatives "wouldn't be as good" as Respeecher's work, Wood confirmed Lucasfilm's main concern was always with their wellbeing and would have pursued other options to prevent putting the Respeecher team in additional danger, but they wanted to persevere with their work despite Russian bombardments. One synthetic-speech artist, Bogdan Belyaev, subsequently volunteered to help fellow Ukrainians displaced by Russia's war.[[585]](#cite_note-Respeecher-585)

 [![Darth Vader's costume was designed by Suttirat Anne Larlarb](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/53/DarthVaderCostumeSDCC.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20220904222514) [![Darth Vader's costume was designed by Suttirat Anne Larlarb](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/53/DarthVaderCostumeSDCC.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/170?cb=20220904222514)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/53/DarthVaderCostumeSDCC.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20220904222514) 

Darth Vader's costume was designed by Suttirat Anne Larlarb

 

Vader's costume was desgined by costume designer [Suttirat Anne Larlarb](/wiki/Suttirat_Anne_Larlarb "Suttirat Anne Larlarb").[[586]](#cite_note-Andor_costumes-586) The first scene shot with Christensen was when he played Anakin Skywalker in a vision seen by Kenobi.[[587]](#cite_note-Sweet_gesture-587) Christensen also played a helmet-less Vader in a bacta tank in the series. The crew knew the actor would have to hold his breath while submerged in the water, so he worked with a dive instructor who helped him build up his breath holds. Christensen was not allowed to breathe through the regulator.[[588]](#cite_note-Christensen_bacta-588) A team of make-up artists spent four to five hours applying make-up on Christensen for him to play Vader in those scenes. He worked very closely with executive creative director of Lucasfilm, [Doug Chiang](/wiki/Doug_Chiang "Doug Chiang"), who gave input into the overall look.[[589]](#cite_note-Christensen_Hollywood-589) Christensen also played Anakin Skywalker during the Order 66 flashbacks.[[590]](#cite_note-New_Kenobi_photos-590) Chow wanted to make Vader's arrival in the [Mapuzo mining village](/wiki/Mapuzo_mining_village "Mapuzo mining village") to be similar to a [horror movie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horror_film "wikipedia:Horror film") where the monster would appear and then disappear. Christensen and McGregor trained with lightsabers for the flashback of Skywalker and Kenobi training[[562]](#cite_note-Return-562) in the [fifth episode](/wiki/Part_V "Part V").[[55]](#cite_note-Part_V-55) They both had dots on their face for the de-aging technology.[[562]](#cite_note-Return-562)

After rumors spread of his return, Christensen was confirmed to be returning to the role of Skywalker on [October 22](/wiki/October_22 "October 22"), 2021, for[[591]](#cite_note-Instagram-591) the [2023](/wiki/2023 "2023") Disney+ series[[592]](#cite_note-Force_TV_Spot-592) *[Star Wars: Ahsoka](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Ahsoka "Star Wars: Ahsoka")* by Ahsoka Tano actress [Rosario Dawson](/wiki/Rosario_Dawson "Rosario Dawson") on her Instagram page. However, she then took down the post.[[591]](#cite_note-Instagram-591) Christensen's return as Skywalker was officially confirmed in the "Force" television spot, which featured new dialogue from Christensen as Skywalker, on [August 13](/wiki/August_13 "August 13"), 2023.[[592]](#cite_note-Force_TV_Spot-592)

### Non-canon history

The *[Darth Vader and Son](/wiki/Darth_Vader_and_Son "Darth Vader and Son")* series of books by [Jeffrey Brown](/wiki/Jeffrey_Brown "Jeffrey Brown") depict Darth Vader of the Imperial era as a loving father to Luke Skywalker and Leia Organa, buying them [ice cream](/wiki/Ice_cream "Ice cream"), playing [tea](/wiki/Tea "Tea") party, and even reading bedtime stories.[[593]](#cite_note-vaderson-593)

In the *[Angry Birds Star Wars](/wiki/Angry_Birds_Star_Wars "Angry Birds Star Wars")* titles, Anakin is the feared "Lard Vader," the feared porcine military commander who seeks to become Emperor, commanding the Pork Side.[[594]](#cite_note-angrybirds-594)

Darth Vader and Darth Sidious appear as the main antagonists in the non-canon *[LEGO Star Wars: The Freemaker Adventures](/wiki/LEGO_Star_Wars:_The_Freemaker_Adventures "LEGO Star Wars: The Freemaker Adventures")*. While probing the Jedi Archives, Vader learns about the existence of a powerful lightsaber called the [Kyber Saber](/wiki/Kyber_Saber "Kyber Saber"), which was made from several kyber crystals. However, the Jedi Master who made the Saber had deemed it too powerful and destroyed it before scattering the crystal throughout the galaxy. Darth Sidious sought to collect all the crystals so he could destroy the galaxy. However, the two Sith Lords were opposed by the [Freemakers](/wiki/Freemakers/LEGO "Freemakers/LEGO"), a scavenging family, and the Jedi [Naare](/wiki/Naare "Naare").[[595]](#cite_note-Announcement_Trailer-595)

In *[Are You Scared, Darth Vader?](/wiki/Are_You_Scared,_Darth_Vader%3F "Are You Scared, Darth Vader?")*, a number of classic villains, such as a [wolfman](/wiki/Wolf "Wolf") and a "[ghost](/wiki/Ghost_(folklore) "Ghost (folklore)")" attempt to terrorize Vader, only for him to either be confused by them or simply not scared. As the story comes to a close, however, readers discover what really has the power to terrify Lord Vader.[[596]](#cite_note-scared-596)

On October 29, 2014, for a Halloween-themed update, a costume of Darth Vader was added to *[The Sims 4](/wiki/The_Sims_4 "The Sims 4")* for playable Sims to wear in-game. The costume is purely cosmetic and offers no gameplay changes.[[597]](#cite_note-Sims_4-597)

### LEGO

Skywalker appeared in "[Kamino Crisis](/wiki/Kamino_Crisis "Kamino Crisis"),"[[598]](#cite_note-CoK-598) a non-canon comic story written by [Martin Fisher](/wiki/Martin_Fisher "Martin Fisher") and published on [October 7](/wiki/October_7 "October 7"), 2023[[599]](#cite_note-jedi-bibliothek-599) in the [101st issue](/wiki/LEGO_Star_Wars_101 "LEGO Star Wars 101") of the magazine [*LEGO Star Wars*](/wiki/LEGO_Star_Wars_(magazine) "LEGO Star Wars (magazine)"). In the comic, Skywalker, Ahsoka Tano and Clone Captain Rex were returning from a successful mission onboard the *Resolute*. After Rex told them that their missions were too easy, the two Jedi planned to test the Captain by manipulating a training session for new clone troopers that was led by Rex. Tano disguised herself as a clone trooper named Tank, while Skywalker disguised himself as clone trooper Thrower to take part in a course in the [Tipoca City Training Facility](/wiki/Tipoca_City_Training_Facility "Tipoca City Training Facility") on Kamino. While they were fighting B1 battle droids that were repurposed as training droids, a voltage peak caused the droids to become much more aggressive and skilled in combat. The droids managed to break out of the training arena, after which Tano and Skywalker, still disguised as clone troopers, joined forces with Rex and other troopers to stop the rogue group of droids. While they were fighting in the hallways of Tipoca City, the clone trooper [Glider](/wiki/Glider_(clone_trooper) "Glider (clone trooper)") went into the control room and destroyed the controls with his blaster, which caused the battle droids to be powered down. As Rex gathered the troopers to thank them, Tano and Skywalker took of their helmets and revealed themselves. They explained that they wanted to test the Captain and Rex responded that he wouldn't call their missions easy ever again. He then invited them to join his bowling team if they ever left the Jedi Order.[[598]](#cite_note-CoK-598)

### Translations

* In the Italian original and prequel trilogies, Darth Vader is known as **Lord Dart Fener**. In 2004, Lucasfilm announced a "referendum" to Italian fans about the changing of the name into Darth Vader for *Revenge of the Sith*, but "Dart Fener" won, and the name was reverted to "Darth Vader" for materials from *The Force Awakens* onwards.
* In French, Vader is called **Dark Vador**. "Dark" is the French word for "Darth" and was applied to later-introduced Sith characters. In French Canada, the name was reverted to "Darth Vader" for materials from *Revenge of the Sith* onwards.
* In Icelandic, Vader is called **Svarthöfði**, which translates to "black head."
* In [Chinese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_language "wikipedia:Chinese language"), Darth Vader is directly transliterated into [Cantonese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cantonese "wikipedia:Cantonese")-[spoken](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Varieties_of_Chinese "wikipedia:Varieties of Chinese") [Traditional Chinese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters "wikipedia:Traditional Chinese characters") as "**達斯·維達**" and in [Mandarin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Chinese "wikipedia:Standard Chinese")-spoken [Simplified Chinese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplified_Chinese "wikipedia:Simplified Chinese") as "**达斯·维德**." The most common translation in Chinese is "**黑武士**" (Dark Knight),[[600]](#cite_note-toysrus-hk-600) although Darth Vader is also translated to "**黑衣勋爵**" (Lord in Black) or "**帝国大将**" (Imperial Grand General) in Simplified Chinese. While Anakin is transliterated as "**安纳金**" in [Hong Kong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong "wikipedia:Hong Kong") (a Cantonese-speaking country) and "**阿纳金**" in Mandarin, Skywalker is paraphrased as "**天行者**" (sky-walker) in Hong Kong or "**任天行**" (travel the sky at will) in other countries.
* In Japanese, Anakin Skywalker and Darth Vader are transliterated and written in katakana as "**アナキン・スカイウォーカー**" and "**ダース・ヴェイダー**" respectively.
* In Korean, Anakin Skywalker and Darth Vader are transliterated and written as "**아나킨 스카이워커**" and "**다스 베이더**" respectively.

According to *[Ultimate Star Wars, New Edition](/wiki/Ultimate_Star_Wars,_New_Edition "Ultimate Star Wars, New Edition")*, [*Darth Vader* (2017) 18](/wiki/Darth_Vader_(2017)_18 "Darth Vader (2017) 18") takes place after the events of *Tarkin*. Next, [*Darth Vader* (2017) 19](/wiki/Darth_Vader_(2017)_19 "Darth Vader (2017) 19") featured the [Second Sister](/wiki/Second_Sister "Second Sister"), who was [killed](/wiki/Death "Death") in *[Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order](/wiki/Star_Wars_Jedi:_Fallen_Order "Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order")*. The events of *Fallen Order* occurred five years after the [fall](/wiki/Great_Jedi_Purge "Great Jedi Purge") of the [Jedi Order](/wiki/Jedi_Order "Jedi Order"), which is dated to 19 BBY by *Star Wars: Galactic Atlas*. Therefore, *Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order* is also set in 14 BBY. As *Darth Vader: Dark Lord of the Sith 18* is between both *Tarkin* and *Darth Vader: Dark Lord of the Sith 19*, the events of the issue must take place in 14 BBY. The events of issue 20 take place immediately following issue 19 as well, as issue 21 immediately following the events of issue 20; therefore, issue 22 must also occur in 14 BBY, as it immediately follows the events of issue 21. Finally, *[Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker: The Visual Dictionary](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Rise_of_Skywalker:_The_Visual_Dictionary "Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker: The Visual Dictionary")* states that [Fortress Vader](/wiki/Fortress_Vader "Fortress Vader") was finished forty-six years before the [Hosnian Cataclysm](/wiki/Hosnian_Cataclysm "Hosnian Cataclysm"), which *[Star Wars: Galactic Atlas](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Galactic_Atlas "Star Wars: Galactic Atlas")* dates to [34 ABY](/wiki/34_ABY "34 ABY"). Therefore, the end of the [fortress](/wiki/Fortress "Fortress")'s construction, and therefore the events of [*Darth Vader* (2017) 23](/wiki/Darth_Vader_(2017)_23 "Darth Vader (2017) 23"), took place in [12 BBY](/wiki/12_BBY "12 BBY"), meaning the construction took two years in total. 291. ↑ [291.0](#cite_ref-Jedi_Fallen_Order_291-0) [291.1](#cite_ref-Jedi_Fallen_Order_291-1) [291.2](#cite_ref-Jedi_Fallen_Order_291-2) [291.3](#cite_ref-Jedi_Fallen_Order_291-3) [291.4](#cite_ref-Jedi_Fallen_Order_291-4) [291.5](#cite_ref-Jedi_Fallen_Order_291-5) [291.6](#cite_ref-Jedi_Fallen_Order_291-6) *[Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order](/wiki/Star_Wars_Jedi:_Fallen_Order "Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order")* 292. ↑ [292.0](#cite_ref-Part_IV_292-0) [292.1](#cite_ref-Part_IV_292-1) [292.2](#cite_ref-Part_IV_292-2) [Obi-Wan Kenobi new series logo](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Obi-Wan_Kenobi "Star Wars: Obi-Wan Kenobi") *[Star Wars: Obi-Wan Kenobi](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Obi-Wan_Kenobi "Star Wars: Obi-Wan Kenobi")* — "[Part IV](/wiki/Part_IV "Part IV")" 293. I LIKE CATS 🐈‍⬛ It was dark and heavy playing the character, it tore me up from the inside. But you've already seen my favorite scene of filming "street scene". It was my introduction to set, and my first day of filming and meeting everyone after 5 months of training 10hrs a day for the role (...) On set I was usually in meditation, staying the headspace of the character, so I honestly don't know what was going on around me. (...) Some scenes required switch back and forth between multiple people. It took a village. (...) I learned all my lines like everyone else. But we found out earlier on that when I spoke with anger it shook the helmet. So we had a voice actor on set, my friend Dorian, he would voice act the scene, and I would act to his intensity while adding my own character choices. We danced together to create the performance alongside my movement coach/consultant Olga Sokolova. Her and I have a secret hand language so she would be giving me notes in real time as well. It was a great big dance, it shouldn't have worked, but it worked out beautifully. (...) Yes, There was. It happened once, there was a tremor. (...) Vader is played by three people, we all worked together to create the best Darth Vader in cinematic history. It's me, it's Hayden , It's Tom. We are a symbiosis. We all contributed our strengths to create the best representation of the character. (...) Hayden and I both act in the Darth Vader scenes, we bring the character and the emotions (and the pain, suffering, anger) I'm 6'7 so when you see a full body shot it looks better having an actor, vs a CGI creation. Tom specializes in the fighting. The fights are Tom. Full body with Helmet On is me, Hayden carries the heaviest burden of all, the pain and betrayal of his best friend and once mentor. (...) Hayden wore the suit, I wore the suit, Tom wore the suit. We all worked together to create the best character we possibly can. We are a team." 571. ↑ [571.0](#cite_ref-Vader_originally_won_battle_571-0) [571.1](#cite_ref-Vader_originally_won_battle_571-1) [571.2](#cite_ref-Vader_originally_won_battle_571-2) [Premium-Era-real](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/0e/Premium-Era-real.png/revision/latest?cb=20241019125517) [Darth Vader Originally Won Obi-Wan Kenobi's Final Battle (Exclusive)](https://thedirect.com/article/obi-wan-kenobi-darth-vader-final-battle-exclusive) by Johnson, Nathan on [thedirect.com](https://thedirect.com) ([July 6](/wiki/July_6 "July 6"), [2022](/wiki/2022 "2022")) ([backup link](https://web.archive.org/web/20220706175516/https://thedirect.com/article/obi-wan-kenobi-darth-vader-final-battle-exclusive) archived on [July 6](/wiki/July_6 "July 6"), [2022](/wiki/2022 "2022")) 572.
